medical_history.chief_complaint: Severe axial dystonia and intense facial grimacing causing marked discomfort and social and physical disability.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The onset of psychiatric symptoms occurred as young adults. The first case began with depression and delusions, treated effectively at first with trifluoperazine. In March 1974, the patient developed choreoathetosis and dystonia. The second case exhibited obsessive-compulsive behavior beginning in 1966, with involuntary movements present for 2 years at the time of examination in 1974. Symptoms in both cases worsened following changes in medication.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Both patients had prior psychiatric conditions treated with antipsychotic medications. The first had acute undifferentiated schizophrenia, while the second exhibited symptoms suggestive of schizophrenia and obsessive-compulsive behaviors.
medical_history.family_history: The second case included a family history of schizophrenia in one sister and obsessive behavior in the mother. The first case had no family history of neurological or psychiatric disorders.
